reviewText:
What to say about Faerie Solitaire? I saw a bunch of my Steam friends playing this and went ahead an bought it a while back, but didnt really crack into it until recently. It was a very pleasant surprise. It's solitaire with a few twists and a little story about a kid who finds faeries in captivity and frees them while seeking out the reason all of this is happening. Nothing too deep about the story, but it does hold your interest well enough, and is a nice fable on its own.
The gameplay itself is simple enough...it is not exactly solitaire, in that rather than match suits until you run out of cards, you are instead trying to build combos to take off the board using your held cards as the base card for said combos. The bigger the combo, the more it is worth. Additionally, you unlock powers such as being able to automatically link a card that would not normally combo, receive extra hold cards to use when you see fit, and build faerie structures that add benefits such as extra undo-s (which you can use to go back one move if you realize you made a mistake), the ability to look at the next card in your deck, and so on.
Each round is made up of nine hands, and there were something like 27 rounds total, broken up into story chapters (each chapter is 3 rounds). Each round has a set of goals, which might include a certain card total combo being reached (8, 10, 12, even 15 in some rounds), acquire a certain amount of points, and fill your charge meter within a certain amount of time. You cant move forward until you meet all the goals, so you may end up repeating a round from time to time.

Anyway, I found this to be a pleasant game with a reasonable amount of challenge, but still something you can do while distracted or feeling particularly unmotivated to do much of anything. I guess what I am saying is it is completely accessible to anybody, can be played in small snippets, and easily fills the gaming void when you aren't sure what else you want to play.

9 out of 10

reviewText:
Hello there, you shiny little gem! What do we have here? Our age old, classic card game that we practically grew up with since Windows 3.0 - or as your grandmother's generic hobby - combined with a pretty fairytale and collectibles? I'm in!

The scene opens up to the realm of fairies, threatened by an unspeakable conspiracy. A dark, evil force that we fail to identify enslaves the inhabitants of the realm for its own dark purposes. A kindly old wizard approaches, and declares us as the only possible candidate to save fairies from their torment... with our solitaire skills? (I owe this joke to my friend  Solanum Nigrum. It was originaly in his review, but I couldn't bear myself not to include it, due to the joke being perfectly definitive.) Yes, it is solitaire. Yes, it has a story... and the story actually ends with a huge cliffhanger, so you'll be anticipating for Faerie Solitaire 2 before you know.

Aside from your usual solitaire gameplay, Faerie Solitaire contains some surprises. You earn cash as you progress through various levels of the story - or in any casual game - to obtain upgrades for your gameplay. The gameplay also sets some goals for you in each level, that raises the stakes a bit more, either with time limits or a certain number of cards that you have to make a combo with. You are also entitled to collect some magical eggs that will hatch into various magical beasts. These beasties gain experience as you play and they may be raised into adulthood for their own achievement set.

All in all, it is a good game for a low price that you can pick to pass some mindless time, with interesting features. I also gotta mention that the art is surprisingly beautiful for a casual game. I adored the profile backgrounds and emoticons! I know, I know, it is girly... But I am a girl anyhow. So I am entitled to my fairies, damn it!

reviewText:
Faerie Solitaire is a great casual game, which is well suited for wasting time in an enjoyable way.  The way the basic game of solitaire is made fun by the way the arrangement of cards shifts and the rewards system that adds a little dimension to an otherwise monotonoous game.

The game was designed for an ancient monitor resolution of 800x600 and so is apt to look quite distorted on a modern widescreen monitor unless you play in windowed mode.  In that mode, the game window is small on a high resolution monitor and may cause some eye strain after long periods of playing.  So plan on short play periods when you are ready for a little casual fun and don't have time for a more serious game.

The developer promised in November 2012 that there would be a high resolution version released in the future and that all now current owners would get a free copy of the new version, which would have its own trading cards, etc.  So from a price point perspective, this game offers some trading cards now and potentially more in the future, which could be sold to further reduce the cost to the player.

reviewText:
You can't go wrong with solitaire. Faerie Solitaire is the game that everyone has played at some point in their life plus a story, rpg elements such as exp and upgrades, and some pleasant background noise.

.Game play.
Your objective is to count. You have a deck of cards from which you draw one card and then you try and place it on a card on the game board before you that either precedes it or follows it--i.e, if you have a 6, you can place it on a 5 or 7. It's very simple and very satisfying if you can get a good count running. Some boards have a gimick such as ice that can be removed if you clear the cards in front of a 'fireball' spell and thorns that can be removed if you clear the row of cards over their roots.

Besides that, you sometimes find eggs if you clear the rows of cards on the board and you can equip the pets inside of them so that they passively gain experience while you play. The pets evolve using ingredients you can find the same way you find their eggs, but their only function is for vanity (and achievements).

.Story/Premise.
You're trying to save the Faerie Land and you progress through each area by playing solitaire. It doesn't make much sense, but... Magic!

.Art style/graphics.
It's colourful and cartoony. The illustrations on the cards and for the pets are cute and the animations for the spells you cast or the combo meter are neat.

.Soundtrack.
It's peaceful. Suitable for a card game.

.Bottom line.
There's not much else to say. Faerie Solitaire is a nice way to pass the time. Definitely worth a look.

Faerie Solitaire is nothing more than what promises to be: a solitaire card game. The game itself, though, is wrapped up in a nice setting with beautiful drawings, pleasant music and sound effects, and a sort of story (don't expect to get hooked on it, though: it's nothing spectacular). The adventure mode presents you with objectives that you need to achieve in order to progress (all related to your solitaire games).

In order to keep you interested, there are also collectable eggs dropped randomly (as far as I can tell) while you play, that you can hatch and evolve into creatures. On the other hand, the gold that you collect by playing can be used to buy upgrades that will make it easier to reach the objectives of the various levels.

All in all, I recommend this game, as each of its levels is a nice way to spend 15, 20 minutes while you are waiting for something like your meal to be ready, or just before going to bed.

reviewText:
Faerie Solitaire is a card game at heart - a time waster.  It's not a hardcore game, it's meant for casual play.  That said, it does what it does well.  If you're going to play a card game on the computer, this should probably be it.  The audio is good, the animations are solid and enjoyable, and the gameplay mechanics are well polished and fun.  There are unlocks and pet evolving - everything a casual game should have to keep you hooked and make you want to keep playing.  There is also a MASSIVE singleplayer campaign of solitaire.  I beat the entire thing before reviewing this game and it took me a solid 7-9 hours.  That's right folks, 7-9 hours of straight solitaire - and I loved it.  The game functions well, does what it sets out to do in a great way, and doesn't try to overextend its reach.

If you're looking for a card game or a gift for a person who plays Windows' solitaire regularly this is the game to buy.  Don't buy it thinking it's something besides a time killer or a casual game.

Pros:

Good audio
Solid mechanics
Huge singleplayer campaign
Unlocks
Comboing is fun and addictive

Cons:

It's just a card game
When you complete one objective towards beating a level it shouldn't display that objective any more on subsequent hands - you'll know what I'm talking about if you play the game

As I said, it's a card game; nothing more, nothing less.  However, if you're looking for that, it's a great game.  It does take the main solitaire game and spin it a little bit creatively, but nothing too much to write home about.  One minor thing I would have changed is the way the audio works - when you go up the audio goes up, when you go down, the audio should go down.  But that's neither here nor there.  I rate this game average as it doesn't do much new, but if you want to play a card game I highly recommend Faerie Solitaire - B

reviewText: Solitaire - Made Easy With MagicThis is solitaire in a fantasy setting. It runs smoothly, has a bit of a story, and allows someone who has never played solitaire before to get into it an interesting way (however not the classical way). The game however is a bit of a grind fest as you have to complete stage after stage which eventually feels like a tedious task. However for those looking for a solid game of solitaire then this is it.

June 4, 2015
I got this game for 95% off, expecting a crappy game but cards to turn a profit. I was surprisingly impressed.

Faerie Solitaire is surprisingly solid and engaging, easy to play and still satisfying with crisp sounds and a nice style. Gameplay is random but still functional at the start, with new mechanics added gradually to alleviate the problems of random card draws. In a few hours, you can 100% any level by pure skill and planning. The progression system is solid, although collecting all the eggs is too random. The only bug that stands out is the first card not counting for Aura Ring if unused. It can be worked around by drawing the next card and using Undo, but it's something that should've been noted and fixed.

It is basically a free game that would be played online or on mobile, but it is polished and engaging enough to be worthwhile. I probably have 30 hours that haven't shown up due to playing offline. Offline play is one strength I would also consider; achievements unlocked offline will pop on Steam when you check the in-game achievements while online. Keeping this in mind, you can save the last Faerie Land purchase or Challenge stage to complete online, hitting all the offline achievements without backtracking.

There is a fair amount to enjoy in this game, but it will get old after some time. But 40 hours of enjoyable gameplay is worth a purchase for those interested. I'd recommend the game at 75% off or better for most players.

I think I snagged this game as a free giveaway from the developer. I didn't really expect to put 17 hours into it. I enjoyed playing this game quite a bit and go back to it from time to time. It's a solitaire game, so it's nothing mind-blowing, but it does have a few interesting features to mix things up. There are obstacles you need to clear to access some cards. Again, nothing drastic, but they do impact the way you play just enough. This is a casual game, so it won't provide any particularly strong challenge.

There are little objectives for each level and 30 reasonably obtainable Steam achievements, though the pet collecting ones will take a bit of time. Achievements are really the only reason to raise pets. There's really not much story to it. I can't even recall the story at the time of this writing.

Not much more to say about this. It's a fun game. A nice relaxing way to pass the time. If you like casual games and/or card games, there's plenty to like in Faerie Solitaire.

reviewText:
Short of it: I loved this game - right up until the cliffhanger ending and trying to find the last two eggs.  I got this game for $1 and had a lot of fun with it, but the ending and the egg drop rate left me not with warm fuzzy feelings but feelings leaning more toward annoyance and anger.  Part 2 has become a huge project with 15 parts and last I checked part 4 wasn't even done.  A remastered version of the original is in the works to fix the egg drop problem, but it means starting the game over.

Long of it: I enjoy solitaire games anyway, but thought the fairy theme was really fun.  I was enjoying the story and the sense that something wasn't quite right and I really wanted to know what happened next.  I felt like I was finding pets on pace to maybe unlock them all by the time I finished story mode.  I really liked that the pets had baby and adult forms, but I felt like the evolving process was too slow.  Then I got to the end of the game and after my initial shock upon realizing that really was the ending, I told myself surely they must have released the second part by now since this game is over three years old.  After some research, I discover that not only have they not released part two, they have turned it into this huge project of 15 parts and they haven't even completed part 4.  However, the really frustrating thing is trying to get the last two pet eggs.  After you clear all the cards in a stack there is a chance that a material will drop (used to evolve your pets), nothing will drop, or an egg will drop.  Then IF it is an egg drop, it is a random drop of an egg from any level and if you already have all the eggs in that level you get no drop.  I'm not big on the math but that means your odds of dropping that last egg or two are ridiculously low.  Check out the forums and read the many frustrated posts of people who have spent 100+ hours on this game and still have not found the last eggs.  The developers have responded and said that instead of patching the game, they will be releasing a remastered version that addresses this issue and removes the randomness from the drops after so long.  However, that was announced in 2012 and whenever it is released it means starting over.
I've put 16 hours into this game and I still have 9 pets to evolve and 2 to find. Like I said, I really enjoyed the story and I like the idea of the pets, but I find the replayability of this game to be really low - aside from the forced replayability of trying to find the last two pet eggs and evolve the pets.

I absolutely recommend this game if you can find it for $1 like I did, if not unlocking all the achievements is ok with you, and if you go in eyes wide open that the ending is a cliffhanger.

Edit - Since writing this review, the developer has decided to release a game called FaeVerse Alchemy which is in early access (still in development).  I have no idea why they would choose to push this in front of Faerie Solitaire 2 (which they agree is overdue).  I understand them pushing it in front of the remaster of the original Faerie Solitaire because they have promised the remastered version as a free update.  Still it's lame.

Faerie Solitaire is a far better game than it has any right to be. As someone who's never dabbled much into solitaire, I figured I would spend an hour looking at this and chuckle at the whole thing. Weirdly, even though the story is a wonderful schlockfest of campy tropes and no connection to the actual gameplay or goals whatsoever, I couldn't stop playing.

Solitaire is a simple and admittedly boring game, one that is meant to pass time when there is nothing else to do and no one to play with. With only the lightest added perks such as monster collecting, light goals to reach, interesting card set ups and the removal of having to match specific suits, FS turns the whole trite affair into an exciting and wildly engaging affair that I couldn't put down for the next 3 days. I found it best served with some podcasts in the background so as not to feel like I was wasting my life away, but there is an amazing amount of content her from such a simple concept.

After it got its hooks in me, every hand I practically twitched when I didn't clear the boardfor fear of missing out on a new monster egg for my collection that might've been hidden behind those last two cards. The impressive difficulty curve the game presents is also kind of amazing, which is not something I was expecting at all. Fascinatingly complex set ups can lead to a surprising amount of forethought and tactical card plays that can make or break a run. Of course, like all games that surround the old 52, there is no garuntee you'll be able to clear the board, but Faerie offers a variety of unlockable tools that make the prospect more and more plausible. One tool in particular can save a hand for total defeat, in which if you can't make a move in 5 turns, you can zap a card and make it your base. It adds an extra layer to an already complex layer of moves, and once I got into the grove I could rip through hands at unbelievable speed. It's hard to describe just how rewarding this game can be without playing it yourself.

Of course, there are flaws. Plenty of them. The art used to differentiate the cards are not very appealing, the soundtrack can become grating, and the voice-acted story is cheesy and oh so teeth-grindingly bad. Somehow, though, this doesn't detract, but somehow amplifies the glory of this weird little game. While I wasn't neccessarily chomping at the bit to hear the next chapter in the riveting saga, there is a genuine aloof passion to the whole story that I can't help but admire. There is tons of great art in the game that just didn't seem to get used on the cards, but they do help stimulate recognition, to the point where I stopped paying attention to the numbers all together. This is not to say the art is bad; quite the contrary, but that goblin they put on the king cards really begged for a punch in the face. Of course for the soundtrack, you can always turn the music off and put something more to your taste on.

Not exactly a game I expected to like, and definitely not a game I'd come to love. Faerie Solitaire is the sort of guilty pleasure I never thought I wanted. I can't recomend this lovely pile of cheese enough.

reviewText: Solitaire may not be a terribly entertaining game, but it does scratch a certain itch in a calming, addictive way. It's pure escapism, a low-calorie nutritionless fluff for the reptilian parts of the brain to feast upon. Faerie Solitaire takes this base and adds a variety of new hooks to keep you going, such as adorable pets to raise, a village to upgrade with hard-earned fae bucks, and a whole lot of imprisoned faeries for your generic male hero to rescue. On top of that, the pace is strangely merciless; you jump from one stage to the next without getting a chance to spend your new gold and resources on upgrades. To do so requires shamefully quitting mid-hand, and to actually quit the game itself requires a few more steps of legwork and runs you past the Challenge Mode gift shop before letting you out.\n\nThe gameplay itself is perhaps a few degrees less brainless than that of actual Solitaire, but it's still a game that mostly plays itself and is almost entirely at the mercy of the way the deck was initially dealt. On the easiest difficulty setting, this doesn't matter; it would take phenomenally bad luck not to meet the meager victory requirements for each stage. On the most difficult, you're more likely to get struck by lightning than to win without grinding endlessly for the consumable items that break the game entirely. Regardless of difficulty, the gameplay is the same, a repetitive series of clicks that gives you just enough of a reward feed to make you feel accomplished. Don't bother with this one; the spell breaks early and if you really need an endlessly addictive time-sink, there are much better perfectly free ones.

Collecting all the pets can be a chore though, since the eggs they hatch from are randomly spawned from game to game, so sometimes you can go dozens of games without seeing an egg. Well, towards the end of the pet collecting anyway. At the beginning you get them at a decent rate, but around the halfway mark it starts to slow down. Also, it takes 'time' to hatch and then mature. Each card you click will tick down it's 'hatching' and/or 'growing timer, so it can take a while.

However, the pet feature is completely optional. This is the kinda game people buy when they either want a coffee break game, or they're a huge fan of solitaire games. Either way, you'll be playing this game a lot normally and the pet feature is a nice thing to do on the side, which for long term players is the only thing left on the side.

There's an upgrade system which will make playing more convieniet, however it doesn't take too long to max those out and afterwards the only thing left is the pet feature and solitaire... which is great too.

If there was a 'Maybe' option for recommendation, I would select that. The game is basically a variant on Solitaire where you have one deck you draw from to grab cards from the playing field to clear the playing field. The playing field has differing sized stacks that may sometimes overlap, as well as quirky 'seals' where a stack is locked until a requirement is met (clearing a specific card or clearing a specific stack).

There are stages, which are broken down into levels, and each level has 9 hands. Each level has a number of objectives that must be completed by the last hand or you fail and must restart the level. It's a pretty simple game and has a friendly atmosphere that is very kid friendly.

I have one complaint about the game though, and as anyone looking through the forums will see it is the same gripe as everyone else; pet eggs and hatching. It is completely luck and time based to acquire the final two achievements, and many people have spent countless hours grinding these out. And it is not as if the pets actually do anything or serve any purpose other than lore and cuteness. The pets are completely pointless and are a huge time sink. I am VERY lucky to have gotten all but one egg (at the time of writing this) in 27 hours of gameplay (idle time spent in my shop when I have nothing to do while watching episodes of Futurama).

BUT aside from that, the game is solid, visually appealing, has a story (which I skipped entirely so no idea how good it is), and the music is pleasing (up until the 20th hour or so). Do I recommend? Maybe. But because I have only two options, I will say 'Yes'.

System: Steam (PC)

o Basically a story involving a character who goes on a journey in a mysterious world. The game continues the storyline as you go through the levels in a artistic view of the surrounding world of the game.

‚Ä¢ Characters: 5/10
o Basically there are a few characters, your character whose identity isnt even known or a focal point, a bunch of faeries who play different roles and make an appearance in the storyline and your pets you can collect and grow.

‚Ä¢ GamePlay: 8/10
o Basically the game is like Solitaire except you can do all sorts of tricks and be encountering certain obstacles which can be destroyed by attempting certain combos. Each level and stage has a unique goal or requirement such as completing a level in a amount of time, having a certain number of combos or making enough money. At the end of each stage you gain a bit of money from you gained during gameplay and as a extra bonus. You can use these extra amounts of money to purchase different abilities and locations - along with the money you also receive or find items during the gameplay which you can use to feed your pet and thus make them stronger.

‚Ä¢ Graphics: 7/10
o The game has a unique art style but pretty much any PC should be able to run this game. Very basic visual design more like a art book. The storyline is depicted through the fancy artwork and the animations within the gameplay and the menus are well done.

‚Ä¢ Sound: 8/10
o The sound effects are like what you would expect in a fairy tale type of setting of a story. The usual magical incantation sound effects and etc. The sounds are actually well done.

‚Ä¢ Music: 7/10
o For each level there's a different track used which plays a soothing calm song representing the stage's environment. The game's menu music is well done, nothing special with the entire OST but it is a nice departure from what you would hear from the usual games as this game's OST fits well with its casual feel.

‚Ä¢ Length: 8/10
o There are several levels and stages with about over 8 chapters with several stages. Going through them and playing the game of solitaire may take you a while - each play should take you about anywhere between 5-10 minutes depending on the number of cards and obstacles.

‚Ä¢ Replay Value: 9/10
o Although there are specific obstacles in each stage the number of cards and which cards are stacked are always different so each time you play any level in any stage it is always different. Along with that even after you finish the game's main storyline there may be some extra items you can purchase or train more pets which will add a few more hours overall to your game time.

‚Ä¢ Player Value: 7/10
o If you are looking for a casual game that doesnt require a lot of PC power - something to get your time by and something that is actually quite simple and can be as fun as a casual game such as regular solitaire - then this is the game for you because it adds more than regular solitaire - a unique way to play the game along with a storyline to boot along with a well fantasy like OST and overall visual design.

This game was much different than I was expecting it to be. Me, thinking it was just 'another digital card game' was mistaken. It's got a story mode that's wonderfully illustrated, and not badly voice acted by any means. Granted, it's loosely [if at all] tied to the gameplay, but having a story to look forward to at the end of every zone was something that I was able to appreciate. With cute collectible pets and powerups that help you clear the board of cards more easily, Faerie Solitare gives a neat, relaxing challenge to anyone who's a fan of card games or casual gaming.

I'm up to 56 games following the Summer Sale, and honestly, Faerie Solitaire may be my greatest gain following the money sink.

The sounds of this game set the mood. It's relaxed, with lute/harp/whatever-esque strums used as you move through menus. You have nature sounds in the background as you play through the game, and you get nice musical overtures when you complete a stage.

The game is pretty-- not ground-breaking graphics or anything, but everything about it looks nice. It's a card game and it understands that. It never tries to be overly fabulous. It's two-dimensional, it's got good artwork, and things have auras and sparkles and glows. Don't let that last bit throw you off-- it's subtle enough that it won't annoy you.

You'll find eggs and materials and stuff like that to grow baby pets into badass not-baby pets. You get dragons and all that good stuff. You also unlock power-ups and improvements to your game; stuff like improved hatching speeds, seeing how many cards you have left in your deck, and cheat codes where you can see what's the next card in the stack.

But the thing that matters the most is that the game is just ‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•ing fun. It's casual and it accepts that. It's the game you play when you're tired but can't sleep, when you don't want to think too hard, or you're in the middle of searching for a match on LoL or whatever you play and it's taking a very long time. The game does what it does well, and it doesn't try to be your favorite game, but it accidentally comes close anyway.

Faerie Solitaire is a casual card game that is a variaton on Solitaire, with a layout similar to Free Cell. However, if all of the cards from the board, you win prizes that can be used to hatch eggs and raise fantasy creatures.  The fantasy creatures are completely non-interactive, and are displayed like museum pieces.  Each set of hands completed advances the fairy tale storyline, which is pretty bland.  The problem with the story is it is released in such small pieces that it is sometimes hard to follow.  The story is boring, but thankfully the card game itself isn't so bad.  Overall, the game is really easy, and doesn't take too much thinking.  A good distraction if you have some time to waste.

A great Solitare game. There's upgrades to buy, and many pets to collect and grow. Collecting all the pets can be a chore though, since the eggs they hatch from are randomly spawned from game to game, so sometimes you can go dozens of games without seeing an egg. Well, towards the end of the pet collecting anyway. At the beginning you get them at a decent rate, but around the halfway mark it starts to slow down. Also, it takes 'time' to hatch and then mature. Each card you click will tick down it's 'hatching' and/or 'growing timer, so it can take a while.

However, the pet feature is completely optional. This is the kinda game people buy when they either want a coffee break game, or they're a huge fan of solitaire games. Either way, you'll be playing this game a lot normally and the pet feature is a nice thing to do on the side, which for long term players is the only thing left on the side.

There's an upgrade system which will make playing more convieniet, however it doesn't take too long to max those out and afterwards the only thing left is the pet feature and solitaire... which is great too.

Overall, this is just a great game and the devs are great people. Back when this game was first released, the devs were generous enough to host many giveaways in various communities, giving away quite a few copies, which is how I got mine.

As for the current price point, I feel $10 is a good price considering that this game has given me more hours than an uncomfortable number of AAA.
